title: Human Leg Amulet
period: Late Old Kingdom to First Intermediate Period
description:
Human right leg in carnelian, as amulet. Both sides alike with no detail. Pierced through top.
Condition: Good.
credit_line: Gift of Evangeline Wilbour Blashfield, Theodora Wilbour, and Victor Wilbour honoring the wishes of their mother, Charlotte Beebe Wilbour, as a memorial to their father Charles Edwin Wilbour

completeness.name: Best
completeness.description: All data has been vetted. Objects generally have quality photos and descriptions.

labels.content: The human leg frequently appears as an amulet, usually as part of a matching pair. Since these were often placed next to the ankles of the deceased, they were meant to protect the legs and feet. As such, leg amulets magically bestowed the deceased with the ability to move in the afterlife. The red-orange color of carnelian symbolized the power and energy essential for this part of the body.

collections.name: Egyptian, Classical, Ancient Near Eastern Art

exhibitions.title: Body Parts: Ancient Egyptian Fragments and Amulets
